I.  THE WOMEN’S FINANCING MARKETPLACE 
 
1.  The REG: Technical Assistance for the Women’s Financing Marketplace, approved in 
November 2020, will facilitate and broaden access to finance for women and women’s businesses 
and communicate ADB’s efforts in this area to encourage more lending to this sector. 1 Many 
financial institutions (FIs) in ADB’s developing member countries (DMCs) have not targeted 
women borrowers and do not recognize the untapped commercial potential. 2 They do not provide 
suitable and affordable products for this clientele and/or lack the awareness of the barriers that 
women or women’s businesses encounter when trying to access financial services.3 The impacts 
of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic have reinforced the importance of a digital 
economy to change business models and to integrate digital channels into how financial service 
providers or businesses engage with customers. 
 
2.  During this period and post-COVID-19, a dedicated online platform can help support FIs 
and their existing and potential women borrowers. The Women’s Financing Marketplace (the 
Marketplace) will, therefore, be innovative in its work and take a digital approach for interaction 
and  engagement.    Among  a  number  of  activities,  the  Marketplace  will:  (i)  aggregate  and 
disseminate products on gender financing within ADB and to the broader external audience;  
(ii)  support  the  identification  of  cutting-edge  technologies  for  FIs  to  achieve  operational 
efficiencies, reach and scale, and/or new product development to digitize business models, such 
as the use of alternative credit scoring models, mobile technology, cloud technology, and online 
delivery channels, which are expected to be piloted in one or two countries (Papua New Guinea 
(PNG) has been identified as the first)), (iii) build capacity for FIs to promote gender responsive 
financial service delivery and women’s businesses to improve viability, as needed, through a 
range of digital toolkits, webinars and online support, (iv) establish linkages to other programs 
and initiatives on enabling access to finance for women, internal and external to ADB4; and  
(v) create a community platform to attract other co-financiers, including potential TA funding 
providers. The capacity building of FIs and women’s businesses will be supported through the 
technical assistance (TA), Subproject 3. 
 
3.  The TA cluster is envisaged to have 4 Subprojects: (i) Design, Set up and Maintenance of 
the Marketplace, (ii) Innovation and Technologies, (iii) Capacity Building, and (iv) Expansion of 
the Marketplace. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE SUBPROJECT 
 
A.  Overall Progress of the Technical Assistance Cluster 
 
4.  This is the third subproject under the REG: Technical Assistance for the Women’s 
Financing Marketplace. The first and second subprojects were approved in November and 
December 2020, respectively, and consultants are being recruited. 
 
B.  Subproject Scope  
 
 
1  Women’s business in this context means micro-, small- and medium-sized women-owned or women-managed 
businesses. 
2  Financial institutions in this context are banks and non-bank financial institutions including microfinance institutions, 
housing finance, and insurance companies, for instance. 
3  Barriers are for example limited financial literacy, insufficient credit history, and lack of collateral. 
4  For example, PSFI’s Microfinance Risk Participation and Guarantee Program or ADB Ventures and SDCC’s Gender 
and Development initiatives or Tech for Impact.

2 
5.  The TA cluster has the following overall outcome: sustainable financial inclusion for 
women and women’s businesses increased and has defined outputs to be delivered by each of 
the four subprojects. Subproject 3 will specifically contribute to the TA cluster output 3: capacity 
building to women and women’s businesses in the first instance and to FIs after further funding is 
secured.  
 
C.  Subproject Outputs and Activities  
 
Output 1: Capacities of women’s businesses and FIs increased. 
 
6.  Emerging evidence from COVID-19 suggests that in lower- and low-income countries, lost 
income will result in an increase in relative poverty for informal workers and their families and that 
compared to men’s lives, women’s economic and productive lives are disproportionately and 
differently affected.5 The hardest hit sectors include retail, trade and service industries such as 
street vending and domestic work- typically low-wage jobs that rely on in-person connections and 
often carried out by women.6 A survey on the impact of COVID-19 on women’s businesses in 
PNG has for example found that 40.9% of smaller or semi-formal businesses have reported a 
temporary halt in operations. 7 
 
7.  While access to finance to adapt business models to the “new normal” environment and 
operate more digitally is one challenge (such as e.g. using mobile payment channels, advertising 
through Facebook, selling through e-commerce platforms) that needs to be addressed, another 
challenge is that often women’s businesses do not have the financial literacy, skills and capacities 
to present bankable projects. Since the TA funds are earmarked for PNG, this subproject will 
therefore support women’s businesses in PNG through various means. Specifically, it will conduct 
tailormade training and coaching sessions, for example, in digital financial literacy, business 
planning, and debt management and other areas, as needed, to sustainably develop their 
business. A suitable training provider will be selected, and existing training curriculum and 
material will be adjusted to meet the needs of the women’s businesses and the new online format. 
Providing training and coaching sessions online in the current environment will reach a wider 
audience and can be screened across multiple countries and regions. It is expected that some 
on-site coaching will remain, once the COVID-19 situation has improved. Further feedback from 
FIs on requirements for lending will also be incorporated.8 
 
8.  Women’s businesses will also be connected with networks (e.g. PNG Business Coalition 
of Women, Business Advocacy Network or Centre for International Private Enterprise) and 
potential accelerators that support women’s businesses through tailor-made support and market 
access possibilities and enhance sharing.9 Women’s business initiatives in PNG are quite strong 
and will be excellent partners for the development of training and coaching, as well as to support 
networking activities. The first pilot activities for supporting women’s businesses will be  financed 
by the Women Entrepreneur Financing Initiative (WeFi) under the Women Accelerating Vibrant 
Enterprises in Southeast Asia and the Pacific (WAVES) program.10 Material or courses prepared

the Marketplace.11 Networking for women’s businesses and FIs can also be expanded through 
the Marketplace. This work will be conducted in coordination with subproject 2, which focuses on 
the digitization of business models. 
 
9.  Further, introducing new digital financial services, specifically geared to enhance gender 
responsive financing or applying a gender lens in the investment/ credit or product development 
process of an FI will require different approaches and new skill sets. FIs will be supported through 
a range of activities, such as specific tailored expert advice, webinars or online toolkits once 
additional funding is secured.   
 
D.  Subproject Cost and Financing 
10.  The TA subproject is estimated to cost $100,000, of which all will be financed on a grant 
basis by WeFi under the WAVES program. The funds will support, among other activities, the 
development of online support through training, webinars, coaching and expert advice. It will cover 
digital production, remuneration, travel, and per diem for international/national consultants and 
miscellaneous expenses.  ADB will seek cost-matching from its client as much as possible. 
 
E.  Subproject Implementation Arrangements 
11.  ADB will administer Subproject 3 and its Private Sector Operations Department, Financial 
Institutions  Division,  will  select,  supervise,  and  evaluate  consultants  in  collaboration  with 
Transaction Support Division and Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department, as 
necessary.
